content:
## Description

In a sentence or two, describe the purpose of this space.
## Search this Space

## Filter by Label

> Info: These are all the labels in use in this space. Select a label to see a list of content the label has been applied to.

## Recently updated content

> Info: This list below will automatically update each time somebody in your space creates or updates content.

## Introduction

Mounting an storage means accessing your store through Databricks DBFS system. The mounted storages reside under Databricks > Catalog > Browse DBFS > /mnt (you need to have a working cluster).

## Azure Blob

### Instructions

1. Create a Databricks notebook.
2. Add this code:

```
container_name = "CONTAINER_NAME" # like "invent-tbretail-datastore"
storage_account = "STORAGE_ACCOUNT" # like "inventtbretail"
access_token = "ACCESS_TOKEN"

dbutils.fs.mount(
  source=f"wasbs://{container_name}@{storage_account}.blob.core.windows.net",
  mount_point=f"/mnt/{container_name}",
  extra_configs={
    f"fs.azure.account.key.{storage_account}.blob.core.windows.net": access_token,
  }
)
```

You can access your container_name and storage_account values in Azure Storage Explorer like this:

access_token is your Primary Key under storage_account. Make it visible to access it.

metadata.title: How to mount an Azure Blob or AWS S3 Bucket to your Databricks environment?

content:
er like this:

access_token is your Primary Key under storage_account. Make it visible to access it.

1. You have to see True value after execution of the code block.
2. You have completed the mounting process!
3. Using below code you will guarantee that the path exists.

```
dbutils.fs.ls("/mnt/{container_name}")
```

## Related articles

[https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/connect/storage/azure-storage](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/connect/storage/azure-storage)

content:
# Migration Guide Template

> [!NOTE]This template is designed for writing migration guides for internal librariesIf this migration requires simple automation scripts (data updates, schema changes, etc.), please prepare and include the scripts in the Guide.

## File Naming Format

`[YYYY-MM-DD]-{Version}-{Feature-Name}-Migration-Guide.md`

Example: `[2025-01-15]-v2.1.0-New-Partition-System-Migration-Guide.md`

## Summary

Briefly explain the purpose and scope of the migration.

- What is changing?
- Why is it changing?
- Which systems/DAGs are affected?

## Version Requirements

- fabbrica >= X.Y.Z
- fabbrica-plugin-invent >= A.B.C
- rocks-â€¦.>= M.N.P
- Other dependencies...

> [!CAUTION]Critical warnings and important considerations

## Migration Steps

### 1. Configuration Changes

Specify which configuration file(s) need to be modified (e.g., `fabbrica.yaml`, `config.yaml`, etc.):

```yaml
# Old Configuration
old_config:
  key: value

(e.g., `fabbrica.yaml`, `config.yaml`, etc.):

```yaml
# Old Configuration
old_config:
  key: value

# New Configuration
new_config:
  key: value
```

#### Environment Variables

```bash
# Environment variables to add/update
FABBRICA_NEW_FEATURE_ENABLED=true
```

### 2. DAG Changes

- daily_dag
- rocket_pandas
- other_dags...

#### Example DAG Update

```py
# Old implementation
class OldDag(DAG):
    def __init__(self):
        # old code

# New implementation
class NewDag(DAG):
    def __init__(self):
        # new code
```

### 3. Schema and Output Changes

```yaml
# Old Schema
old_schema:
  id: string
  date: timestamp
  value: integer

# New Schema
new_schema:
  id: string
  date: timestamp
  value: integer
  status: string  # New field
```

- table_1Change Type: {Schema Change}Impact: {High/Medium/Low}
- table_2Change Type: {Format Change}Impact: {High/Medium/Low}

#### Data Compatibility Notes

m/Low}
- table_2Change Type: {Format Change}Impact: {High/Medium/Low}

#### Data Compatibility Notes

- [ ] Breaking ChangesList any breaking changesImpact on existing data
- [ ] Backward CompatibilityOld version can read new format: {Yes/No}New version can read old format: {Yes/No}Migration script provided: {Yes/No}

### 4. Function, Class and Data Changes

Specify any changes in:

- Function signatures or return types
- Class parameters or attributes
- Data structure requirements
- Database schema modifications

Example:

```py
# Old function signature
def process_data(input_data: Dict) -> None

# New function signature
def process_data(input_data: Dict, config: Optional[Dict] = None) -> List[str]
```

## Troubleshooting

### Common Issues and Solutions

1. Problem: {Error message}Solution: {Solution steps}
2. Problem: {Error message}Solution: {Solution steps}

## References
